step_by_step_thinking: The patient presents with septic shock, DIC, and pelvic infection signs. The phenol test identifies a phosphorylated N-acetylglucosamine dimer with fatty acids, indicating a bacterial capsule. Neisseria species (e.g., N. gonorrhoeae) have capsules and are gram-negative coccobacilli. Blood cultures would show encapsulated, gram-negative coccobacilli forming grey colonies on charcoal blood agar. Other options do not match the capsule structure or clinical context.
